Title: The Uncarved Block in Taoism ｜ Tao Te Ching Explained ｜ Chapter 15

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters were subtle, mysterious, profound, responsive, and had unfathomable knowledge.
Content.Text: The ancient masters were subtle, mysterious, profound, responsive. The depth of their knowledge is unfathomable.

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters were careful, deliberate, and slow to action, like crossing a winter stream.
Content.Text: Watchful, like a man crossing a winter stream. Alert, like a man aware of danger.

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters were courteous and yielded to others, treating them like guests.
Content.Text: Courteous, like visiting guests. Yielding, like ice about to melt.

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters were simple, unadorned, and open to all possibilities, like uncarved blocks of wood.
Content.Text: Simple, like uncarved blocks of wood. Hollow, like caves. Opaque, like muddy pools.

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters understood the value of hollowness, emptiness, and waiting for the mud to settle.
Content.Text: Who can wait quietly while the mud settles? Who can remain still until the moment of action?

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters understood the importance of wu-wei and detachment from the need to be in the center of everything.
Content.Text: If you can detach yourself from the need to be in the center of everything, you will leave yourself open to seeing things muddier.
